description: From Ecclesiastical Ancient Greek ἑτεροουσιος (heteroousios, “of a different nature”), formed from ἕτερος (héteros, “another, different”) and οὐσία (ousía, “nature, being”).

adjectives.description: heteroousian (comparative more heteroousian, superlative most heteroousian)

entries.meaning: having different essence or substance, especially with reference to the first and second persons of the Trinity
